GRM101.name: Elementary German I
GRM101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM101.description: German language, civilization, and culture for beginning students. Work on all language skills with emphasis on speaking.

GRM102.name: Elementary German II
GRM102.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM102.description: Further study of German language, civilization, and culture for beginning students. Continued work on all language skills with emphasis on speaking.
GRM102.prerequisite: (GRM 101) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM201.name: Second-Year German I
GRM201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM201.description: Intermediate-level development of all language skills. Reading, viewing, and discussion of a broad range of cultural materials from the German-speaking world.
GRM201.prerequisite: (GRM 102) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM202.name: Second-Year German II
GRM202.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM202.description: Further intermediate-level work on all language skills, based on topics such as popular music, literature, film, current events, and culture. Transition course to advanced work in German studies.
GRM202.prerequisite: (GRM 201) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM250.name: German Literature and Culture in English
GRM250.description: Selected representative texts or themes in the cultures of German-speaking countries.

GRM290.name: Independent Study
GRM290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM290.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
GRM290.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department.

GRM301.name: Third-Year German: Global Germany
GRM301.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM301.description: Advanced speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills. Intensive work with authentic texts dealing with contemporary issues in the German-speaking world. Selected review of grammar and syntax. Focus on the creation of German identity through migration, immigration, and exile.
GRM301.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM302.name: Third-Year German: Nature in Germany
GRM302.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM302.description: Advanced speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills. Intensive work with authentic texts dealing with contemporary issues in the German-speaking world. Selected review of grammar and syntax. Focus on the natural world and our often unnatural technologies that interfere with our ecological order. Intensive work with texts and films dealing with forests, gardens, plants, natural explorers, pollution and atomic disaster.
GRM302.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM303.name: Third-Year German: German Genders
GRM303.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM303.description: Advanced speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills. Intensive work with authentic texts dealing with contemporary issues in the German-speaking world. Selected review of grammar and syntax. Focus on the exploration of gender in German culture, from linguistic forms to social roles.
GRM303.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM304.name: Third-Year German: German Media
GRM304.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM304.description: Advanced speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills. Intensive work with authentic texts dealing with contemporary issues in the German-speaking world. Selected review of grammar and syntax. Focus on German media throughout history. Intensive work with films, images, written texts, advertising, news, social media, video games, and other forms of expression.
GRM304.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM311.name: Business German
GRM311.description: Development of proficiency through readings, discussions, and assignments based on materials dealing with the German economic system and Germany in world trade. Taught in German.
GRM311.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM325.name: Third-Year German: Oral Communication
GRM325.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM325.description: Development of listening comprehension and oral communication in German beyond the intermediate level. Expansion of vocabulary, use of idiomatic expressions and review of grammatical structures relevant for speaking.
GRM325.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM341.name: German Literature and Culture Before 1918
GRM341.description: Historical, social, and cultural developments in the German-speaking world before 1918 as revealed in textual material in German, including literature, essays, and film.
GRM341.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German placement test.

GRM342.name: German Literature and Culture since 1918
GRM342.description: Historical, social, and cultural developments in the German-speaking world since 1918 as revealed in textual material in German, including literature, essays, and film.
GRM342.prerequisite: (GRM 202) or designated score on German Placement test

GRM420.name: Advanced German (W)
GRM420.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
GRM420.description: Advanced language skills using a variety of media. Review of grammar and syntax with attention to idiomatic usage and stylistic variation. Major writing project.
GRM420.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

GRM435.name: 18th and 19th Century German Literary Studies (W)
GRM435.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM435.description: Literary and cultural texts from a given period before 1919 such as the Enlightenment, Romanticism. Representations of cultural identity, social issues and intellectual debates through literature and other texts. Major writing project.
GRM435.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

GRM445.name: 20th Century and Contemporary German Literary Studies (W)
GRM445.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM445.description: Literary and cultural texts from a given period since 1919. Representations of cultural identity, social issues and intellectual debates through literature, film and other texts. Major writing project.
GRM445.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

GRM455.name: Major Themes in German Cultural History (W)
GRM455.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM455.description: Evolution of key cultural issues. Use of cultural artifacts in tracing developments across time. Topics such as nationalism, minorities in Germany, literary genres, literacy and popular cultures. Major writing project.
GRM455.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

GRM460.name: Linguistic Analysis of Modern German
GRM460.description: Analysis of grammatical, lexical, phonological and cultural aspects of German and comparison with English. Course taught in German.

GRM461.name: Applied Linguistics for German Learners and Teachers
GRM461.description: Overview of applied linguistic topics relevant for both students of German and future teachers of German. Issues of contemporary language use, the connection between culture and language. Overview of second language acquisition principles. Introduction to effective audiodidactic or pedagogical techniques for language and culture learning.
GRM461.prerequisite: GRM 301 or GRM 302 or GRM 303 or GRM 304 or GRM 311 or approval of department

GRM490.name: Independent Study
GRM490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM490.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
GRM490.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department.

GRM491.name: Special Topics in German Studies
GRM491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM491.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis.

GRM492.name: Capstone Project
GRM492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM492.description: Preparation of a paper or project that synthesizes the student's academic experiences in the major(s). Integration of linguistic, cultural and literary studies in German.
GRM492.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

GRM493.name: International Internship
GRM493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM493.description: Experience of German life and language through participation in an approved international internship program.
GRM493.restrictions: Not open to sophomores. Approval of department.

GRM499.name: Senior Thesis Research
GRM499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM499.description: An individual research project supervised by a faculty member that demonstrates the student's ability to do independent research and submit or present a major paper.
GRM499.restrictions: Open to seniors. Approval of department.

GRM800.name: Reading German
GRM800.description: German grammar and syntax, with emphasis on reading and translation in specialized fields.
GRM800.restrictions: Open to graduate students or approval of department.

GRM803.name: Foundations of Contemporary Language Teaching
GRM803.description: Theoretical and research foundations for communicative and proficiency-oriented instruction of World languages with implications for the classroom.

GRM805.name: The German Language: Relationships, Development, and Varieties
GRM805.description: Methodology and sources in the linguistic study of German. Periodization, phonology, morphology, syntax, and lexicon. Dialects, social variants, and expatriate German. Relationship to other languages.

GRM815.name: The Scholarship and Practice of Teaching German Culture
GRM815.description: Methodologies for teaching culture in the foreign language classroom. Definitions of culture and the interrelatedness of language and culture. Practical application of theory in the development of strategies for teaching culture in the German classroom.

GRM820.name: German Literature and Culture: Theory and Practice
GRM820.description: Theoretical approaches to the study of literature and culture and their application. Research methodologies for literary and cultural studies.

GRM862.name: German Studies: Constructions of Identity
GRM862.description: Aesthetic representations of cultural strategies and theories of self-definition in selected historical periods. Theories of subjectivity. Development of the bourgeois individual. Identity and gender.

GRM863.name: German Studies: Constructions of Community
GRM863.description: Aesthetic representations of group identification in selected historical periods. Nationalism. Concept of the Kulturnation. Role of religious, regional, or linguistic affiliations. Formation of communities based on ethnicity, class, and gender.

GRM864.name: German Studies: Cultural Norms and Values
GRM864.description: Literary and non-literary texts as affirmation, subversion, or critique of aesthetic and social norms in selected historical periods. Role of the artist or intellectual in society. "High" versus "low" culture. Consumerism.

GRM865.name: German Studies: Culture in Context
GRM865.description: Society and the dissemination of cultural knowledge, practices, and values in selected historical periods. Educational and political institutions and cultural politics. Literary and cultural marketplace.

GRM890.name: Independent Study
GRM890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM890.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

GRM891.name: Special Topics in German Studies
GRM891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM891.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis for graduate students.

GRM892.name: Seminar
GRM892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
GRM892.description: Directed original research on current topics in German studies.

GRM893.name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
GRM893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM893.description: Examination of a theme, topic, or genre from several different national and disciplinary perspectives in the appropriate cultural and socio-historical context. Significant texts and important critical analysis selected from Great Britain, Spain, France, Germany, the Americas, and others.

GRM898.name: Master's Research Project
GRM898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM898.description: Directed research leading to a master's project in partial fulfillment of Plan B master's degree requirements.

GRM899.name: Master's Thesis Research
GRM899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM899.description: Directed research leading to a master's thesis, used in partial fulfillment of Plan A master's degree requirements.

GRM990.name: Doctoral Independent Study
GRM990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM990.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual doctoral student and a faculty member in areas supplementing the regular course offerings.

GRM991.name: Special Topics in German
GRM991.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
GRM991.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis for doctoral students.

GRM999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
GRM999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
